title: Data Mining and Data Warehouses

author: Marko Grobelnik, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: The conference, called CKD, is conference on well, data analytics and semantics nowadays, so it used to be more like data mining and data warehouses 10 years ago when we started this and since the area involved a lot and it's in many cases underlying area to everything.
What we do.
So for every single search on the Internet.
Basically we use some of these technologies so that.
This was basically about this topic, so this included everything from statistical data analysis to.
So social network analysis and a little bit of semantic technologies so.
Maybe just to send the conference was yesterday already.
I can say a little bit what was discussed.
Maybe I would point out invited talk which was by a Swan sitting up there on the topic, which I guess addresses everything what we do.
So that was our privacy advocates threatening the future of science.
Why?
Because as we all know, the paradigm of science changed a lot in the last.
Let's say 20 years, so the science used to be very model driven.
So from the idea down to the reality now the size got very much data driven.
So from the data we we try to understand the models we extract the models.
Now of course to do this kind of science.
We need data now, of course, researchers used to have data and since we have honest intentions, so usually was never really a problem to get it.
But for today's standards, if you want to be successful researcher in the area of data mining, you need a lot of data.
Alot of data means Twitter Facebook log files, which of course suffered and privacy in many ways.
And of course, researchers like us.
So for us it's actually quite hard to get.
This kind of datasets still we have access here and there, but not always.
So the topic was really about our policy.
Advocates, lawyers from these big companies, or from anywhere else actually threatening to stop this kind of developments on a large scale.
So talk was recorded.
I recommend to to check it for all of you so.
OK, this was quick summary of them, but at the top the rest we had something like 14 papers on different areas like well text mining and semantic technologies.
So these were mainly results from EU projects like series of FT-7 projects which we are running data mining and machine learning and some some of the applications which we are so jealous.
I and University AI groups are working on so much.
